scenes.heading: INT. MORNING - KITCHEN

dialogues.text: You light a fire early in your girlhood. You stoke it and tend to it. You protect it at all costs.
You keep it secret. You let it burn - a white hot light at the center of yourself.
You look into the eyes of other girls and see their fires flickering there, under the surface.

It’s from this point - this fire - you can create, and fight and push your way through the world. It’s from this fire that you can birth something new - a new version of yourself, or a whole new person who didn’t exist before you squeezed them into the world.
A person who will one day pee in your face without blinking.

scenes.heading: INT. LIBRARY - LATER THAT MORNING

dialogues.text: The problem is I just don’t enjoy the company of moms.
I feel like beginning a friendship with another woman simply because we are both mothers is repugnant.
I mean, if I happened to meet a beautiful, smart, hilarious woman and we became friends... Someone who would get wine drunk on a
What’s your name little buddy? Can you sing it?

scenes.heading: INT. LIBRARY - LATER

dialogues.text: Do you like paint and sip?
Oh, we chatted at Mommy Baby Yoga!
Oh no. I used to do more immersive art- sculptures and found materials.
Me too. I used to live in the city and spent my lunch break at the modern like every day.
Oh I had work that showed at the modern once.
I used to be a stripper. If you can believe that.
Kefir. Homemade- with chia seeds and cardamom. Do you want one for your son?
Oh that’s ok. I gotta get him home for his nap.
Maybe we’ll see you next week?

scenes.actionPreview: 5 5 As Book Babies wraps up, all of the moms and nannies start collecting their belongings. No, I don’t want to do that.
Let’s see who can lie here and be the quietest. I bet I’m gonna win.
Shhh. It’s the quiet game. Quiet as a mouse.
Maybe if I don’t move he won’t see me.

scenes.heading: INT. KITCHEN - AFTERNOON

dialogues.text: Baby - show daddy how you balance your trains! He hasn’t seen that.
So I really shouldn’t have bothered to write out that whole report for him, because they didn’t need it and didn’t even read it.
It really was. Sometimes I swear they don’t realize I have a life and would rather be home with you guys than typing up reports at 11pm on a Thursday from my hotel room.
Well, we had a fine week. We went to Book Babies.
I thought you hated Book Babies?
Oh I do. It was an accident, truth be told, but
You’re still alive, ya ol’ furball?
She is the cat who will never die.
No. I shouldn’t have brought it up. I’m just having some odd side effects maybe of perimenopause? I’m not sure. Weird hair sprouting up?
No! Lower back. And kind of my toes too. I don’t know. I just feel off. I feel like I have this heightened sense of smell - kind of like when I was pregnant. The cat’s butt smells disgusting to me.
And my teeth seem to be getting sharper. Look!
Oh yeah. Definitely. Your teeth look so weird. This is real and not in your head.
(CONT’D) I’m sorry, but honey you always think something is wrong with you.
Well, that’s the thing about being a hypochondriac - one day I will be right! And then you’ll be sorry.

scenes.heading: INT. BEDROOM - NIGHT

dialogues.text: (loud whisper) I can’t remember the last time I washed this shirt.
(loud whisper) I never washed any of my clothes
(loud whisper) I mean, it’s just like... what’s the point? I always hated hard pants. I’m giving in to just a soft- pants lifestyle.
(loud whisper) I’m the housewife I never wanted to be!
I thought this is what you wanted.
I did, I do. But maybe I need to find a part-time job or something?
It’s just the math doesn’t totally add up. The likelihood of you making more than we would have to pay a sitter-
I know. And there aren’t really part time gallery jobs. Or part time nannies.
Yeah. You just gotta hold on till
Then I think - how dare I complain?
I would kill to get to stay home with him every day, for what that’s worth.

dialogues.text: I want to come to this exhibit.

Yeah yeah, you think you do.
This is my little book of weird....
(CONT’D) I took that photo in Prague. Look - I collect things or take pictures of things I find interesting.
No I found it on the street in front of some dorms and thought it was so romantic.

Make a plan ... draw up a schedule.
I’m sure you’re right. I’ll try.

scenes.heading: INT. GROCERY STORE - DAY

dialogues.text: (speaking aloud as she pushes the cart) I’m hysterical. I’m hormonal and hysterical. I’ve always thought of myself as like... a smart woman who sometimes got a little upset but was mostly cool to hang out with.
Oh my gosh, Hi Sally! What are you doing here?
Visiting my mom for the weekend!
Baby, this is Sally. She took over at my job at the gallery, after you were born.
He’s super cute. Do you just love getting to be home with him all the time? It must be so wonderful.
Um. Great question. (The mother really considers this)

(CONT’D) I feel as though societal norms, gender expectations, and plain old biology have forced me to become this person who I don’t recognize. I am angry all the time - like all the time. I would one day like to direct my own artwork toward a critique of these modern-day systems which articulates all this but my brain no longer functions as it did before the baby and I’m just really dumb now. I am deeply afraid I will never be smart or happy or thin again. Oh and I’m pretty sure I’m turning in
Do you just love getting to be home with him all the time? It must be so wonderful.
I love it. I love being a mom.

We used to play dogs too. My son and I. It was so fun and he just loved it. (then to the boy)
She bares her teeth at the boy who giggles. She wags her head back and forth and laughs a hearty and genuine laugh.
You did? I didn’t know you had kids.

dialogues.text: In Hindu mythology, Sarama is a she- dog serving the warrior-god Indra.
She is the mother to all clawed creatures.
In Greek Mythology, we can point to
If my mother were still alive I would have some serious questions for her.
I’d ask her if she ever hated my father? How did she deal with the anger? The resentment for all that she didn’t do? And all he got to do with his life? (MORE)
I’d ask her if her body ever returned to normal? Or her mind? I’d ask her if she ever regretted becoming a mother? But I can’t ask her that. I’d give anything to be able to ask her.

How can we be out of milk?

dialogues.text: I don’t care that he doesn’t want you. I have been doing night nights every night of every day for two hundred years and they are fucking killing me. You have to do night night. IT’S YOUR NIGHT NIGHT TURN!
Okay. But for the record I really don’t like the term “night night”.

scenes.actionPreview: 77 77 She and her son saunter into Book Babies before it’s begun. Her son has on a collar with dog tags. And she doesn’t mind. Jen spots her and waves. Her son barks. The mother doesn’t flinch. He’s a dog today. Everyone takes their seats with their children. The leader starts a peppy round of Wheel

scenes.heading: INT. LIBRARY - LATER

dialogues.text: I’m loving your hair. It’s so wild.
Oh thanks. I guess that’s what washing it will do.
And your sweater is cool too.
You should join us for our Friday morning hike!
I can’t hike very far these days.
Yeah, how are you feeling? Can I?
Sorry. My sense of smell is so strong right now.
Tell me about it. I threw up from the smell of the trash this morning.
Of course - you’re pregnant. That’s when it starts. It’s like a change in the genetic make-up. We don’t talk about the cellular change that happens to us when we become mothers.
That is so right on. We don’t.

Not to mention that the whole concept of motherhood that we are sold is such bullshit - you’re going to be expected to figure this whole thing out alone without any village to speak of, you’re going to get no maternal benefits from the government, you’re going to be mocked in popular culture, and there’s basically a billion dollar industry that’s designing products made to make you feel like you’re a terrible mother! (then, to Liz who is shocked)
I mean, you’re totally right. My sister who lives in Berlin now got two years paid maternity leave.
(CONT’D) I can’t believe I’m going to go through that all again. Birth.
How do you think Daniel will do?

I don’t know - it’s kind of hard for the men to see us like that. He loves telling the story of my first birth. And how the doctor turned to me and said “it’s time to get that baby out” and a vein started popping in my forehead and I turned into like a wild animal. I know he was impressed.
(a little light goes off for her)
Oh my god yes. My husband says the same thing. That the sounds coming out of me were pure animal. He almost passed out. But he’s not good with blood.
Do you ever feel like the big secret is that we are gods?
Mothers. We fucking create life. We make life.
WHOAAAA. You are blowing my freakin’ mind.
We’re so powerful. Men must be terrified of us. Look at you!

dialogues.text: I don’t totally understand I guess.

Yes. He wanted to be domesticated. I was against that.
But I haven’t had to lie with him for hours on end to get him to fall asleep - I just give a little growl and he goes to bed on his own.
I don’t want to criticize. It’s just maybe a little confusing for him is all.
You have to see how weird this is!
No I don’t. What’s the problem?

scenes.heading: INT. NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM - LATER THAT DAY

dialogues.text: I can’t believe it! Here you are!
Jen! Wow - hi. It’s weird to see you in the wild - out of context.
(sotto - not noticing the husband) I’ve been thinking about that conversation in the library non- stop.
Yes. That thing you said about how mothers are mocked in popular culture -
Your wife is amazing. We’re all trying to get her in our crew!
Oh poo. Next time. Come on, kiddos!
I think I’m having a bit of a realization. Maybe it’s all the dead animals everywhere I look- makes you think about your mortality.
I don’t think I’m an artist anymore.
No, you don’t seem upset at all.

Because... I have this running list of all the things I’m not doing every day - all the ways I’m falling behind as an artist. And I feel like if I could just focus on what I AM doing I would be much happier.
I am just a mom now. I should focus on being the best mom I can be - enjoying these moments with him, because this isn’t going to last.
And being an artist is such a silly, self-absorbed thing to be.
(CONT’D) I think there’s sort of a relief in just letting it all go, you know?
Okay. If that’s what you want.

I mean, if I’m gonna do it, I should just commit. Right?
And you remember that I said I would meet up with my grad school friends in the city tonight, right?
It’s not babysitting when it’s your own kid.
Whatever. You know what I mean. I’m on bedtime duty. And you are going to go have a grown up dinner.
Yep. At 9 pm. Four hours later than I usually eat.

scenes.heading: INT. HIP CITY RESTAURANT - LATER

dialogues.text: It’s got like an ironic wink to it.
I didn’t get that. I feel like you have to come from a certain background to feel that irony.
You know work that is examining social media - like my piece- is tricky. We’ve lost some objectivity.
(trying to be part of the conversation)
I’m working on a video piece about one woman’s day, taken over 24 hours side by side with an actress who is acting out that same day in that very same space. Masturbating, shitting. All of it.
But how will you know which woman is the woman.
Exactly. That’s the genius of it.
Me? Um. No. I’m not working on anything. Nope.
We have a beautiful seabass tonight served in a white wine reduction, as well as a homemade cavatelli with chantrelles and fiddlehead ferns.
Oh, my kid and I have this joke about fiddlehead ferns.
You probably have to be there. He has this little two year old accent. It’s like a lisp. ‘feeeedle dee dee’.
Could I have the cavatelli but without the chantrelles?
Yes she’s six. She’s amazing. She’s in first grade at a music academy.
Wow! Is it ever hard for you to balance with your work? Like motherhood and art? How’s that all going?
Not really. I mean, listen, thank god for Kristy. I couldn’t do it without my nanny. Of course. (MORE)
Oh Freida! Your application for the founders grant - did you do it?
Barely! I turned it in at like two am. I’m such a fucking idiot. You?
Oh I turned it in weeks ago. Now we wait.
I didn’t get my application in yet.
I hate it when they call me Ma’am.
I’m a cow. I’m a zen cow in a soothing green field.
Did you make it to the Simiac exhibit at the AFA gallery?
Have you been to Jermaine’s installation at the Frick?
I’m dying to get to the nighttime exhibit at the Rubin!
Insignificant. Oh, this kale is not sitting well.
(yelling to nobody and everyone) I could crush a walnut with my vagina!

scenes.heading: INT. KITCHEN - AN HOUR LATER

dialogues.text: I didn’t want to wake you up.
You know I have my phone on silent at night.
Okay, fine - I got a little drunk.
Why did it make you feel like shit?
Because I’m not doing anything with my life. Because they think I’m just a mother now. Which I am. I mean, I know I am. But they think it’s pathetic and it made me feel pathetic.
They don’t have any clue. They don’t have kids. They don’t know what they’re missing.
Naya does. She has a kid. And she works all the time. And she’s successful and happy and I don’t understand how she is able to do all that.

At some point you’re going to have to start accepting that we’ve made some choices over the years that landed us here. (then very pointed) I don’t know about you, but I wouldn’t trade those choices for the world.

scenes.heading: INT. LIBRARY - DAY

dialogues.text: What? You gave me this book.

(CONT’D) I remember when my kids were little. I had a hard time keeping everything straight also. No sleep for years, holding them through ear aches and stomach aches and bad dreams. It’s enough for any person to lose their bearings.
You just didn’t seem like a mother to me.
You didn’t recognize it? You look into the eyes of other women, and see that fire flickering behind the eyes-
The pain and sacrifice. The shared bond of all you’ve given up for the continuation of the species.
It’s so much more encompassing than I could have known.
It changes you. Connects you to some primal urges.

scenes.actionPreview: 118 118 The mother enters the library pushing her stroller with her son asleep in it. She struggles to get inside without waking him, but manages. She beelines for the counter, where Norma is organizing books. She clunks the book The Field Guide to Magical Women down on the counter. Norma looks at t

scenes.heading: EXT. LIBRARY - CONTINUOUS
scenes.actionPreview: 119 119 The mother wanders out of the library in a daze, book still in hand.

scenes.heading: INT. KITCHEN - NIGHT

dialogues.text: It just doesn’t make sense to me.
The cat died and you didn’t even call me?
It was a pretty traumatic morning.
I guess I’m getting used to doing things by myself.
This has made some things really clear to me though-
I’m not doing okay. You must see that. I’m not okay. I’m not happy.
You said that’s what you wanted.
So quick. No protestations from you! And I keep running over that conversation in my head. Because it would have been so nice for you
Because somewhere you were getting what you’ve always wanted. For me to be a stay at home mom.
Just like your mother. And her mother. A sweet deal for you. You have your job and I have mine. Only my job has no pay and no appreciation and no vacation days and includes washing your underwear.
I didn’t say that. This feels like a trap.

You feel trapped? Do you have any fucking clue how trapped I am? I’ve found myself in a fucking 1950s marriage somehow and I have no idea who I am anymore and all I do is take care of our son and you and the fucking cat- before I killed her.
It was your idea to quit your job. I didn’t suggest that.

You’re right. I agreed to it, but I had no fucking idea what I was agreeing to. I didn’t realize I would feel like a single parent who has zero help and has to give up my dreams to take care of everyone! I don’t even know who I am anymore!
I don’t know what to say. I didn’t know you felt like this.
HOW CAN YOU NOT SEE ME? I’m wilting while you’re out succeeding.
You think I want it like this? I don’t want to be married to my mother. I don’t want to feel your resentment the moment I enter my house.

You aren’t the person I married either. The person I married let things go that weren’t important, and was tough as shit. She was weird and excited about things in the world, like reading books and not just watching reality tv and passing out after her second glass of wine.
It’s disappointing. For me too. I don’t know how we ended up here.
She fucking died in childbirth. And she’s not coming back.

Where did you go? MOTHER’S MOTHER I needed some space, so I went walking in the woods.
I thought you weren’t going to come back. MOTHER’S MOTHER I will always come back. I’m your mama forever, and I will always come back.

scenes.heading: INT. LIVING ROOM - LATER

dialogues.text: (CONT’D) (calmly) I think we need a separation.
(also calm) I’m really confused - I don’t understand how we got here.
I know you are. Because I haven’t been sharing with you everything that’s been going on with me. But to be fair, you also haven’t been asking.

This agreement we made, that I would stay home and you would go to work isn’t working for me anymore. I need... space. I don’t even know how to - I don’t know who I am or what I need. I need to dig around in the dark and find myself again.
Do you regret having a kid?
No. I don’t. But I had no clue what we were actually getting into. If I could go back in time, I would have made us sit down and work out a more equitable way to do this parenting thing.
I would have been open to that.

scenes.actionPreview: 126 126 The mother comes inside and sees her husband’s back to her, prepared to not talk again. She looks to him and he doesn’t turn. She starts to go toward their room, instead she comes and sits down next to him, looking right at him. He is surprised. He nods. August 30, 2022 89 July 30, 2022 90 T

scenes.heading: INT. BEDROOM - THE NEXT MORNING
scenes.actionPreview: 127 127 The husband packs up a bag, throwing his clothes into his suitcase, defeated. The mother stands in the doorway looking on, feeling bad but also sure.

scenes.heading: INT. KITCHEN - MORNING
scenes.actionPreview: 128 128 The mother looks out the window and sees her husband driving away. She sighs, unsure if this is right. The heavy skillet onto the stove, pat of butter. Hashbrowns. The mother stares as her son plays at her feet. Everything is the same. But everything is different. She gets down on the floor

scenes.heading: EXT. HIKE - MORNING
scenes.actionPreview: 129 129 The mother, her son and Jen, with her two kids, Liz and her kid, and Miriam and her kid all hike through the beautiful forest. The kids are either in backpacks, or walking themselves. The mother takes in the nature around her.

scenes.heading: EXT. MEADOW - LATER THAT MORNING

dialogues.text: Thank you for letting us come along. This is so beautiful.
Yeah. Sometimes you just gotta sweat to feel alive.
So what did you do before you had your kids?
Yeah. Worked 80 hour weeks. I made more money than my husband - I like to remind him of that sometimes. It was too intense though-
How do you like staying home? You seem really good at it. It’s totally intimidating.

Sometimes I like it. A lot of the time I feel like I have nothing to use my brain for. Except organizing our schedule or researching the new strollers. I use my law degree to read the preschool contracts.
I thought I would like being a stay at home mom. But it’s just not been good for me.
You’re allowed to change your mind.
Can I admit something terrible? I fantasize about running away from it all sometimes. I dream about a faded beach chair and a good book and not talking to anyone for a week.

That’s not terrible at all. Once when I really needed a break I told my husband that I had diarrhea and I locked myself in the bathroom and read magazines in a bubble bath for hours. And I was so fucking happy.

scenes.actionPreview: 130 130 While the kids and some of the other mothers play, the mother finds herself sitting next to Jen on a rock, grabbing a sip of water. September 26, 2022 91 September 26, 2022 92 emails at 2 am, working dinners. The corporate world does not respect mothers. It’s not the life for having littles.

scenes.heading: INT. SUBURBAN MANSION - NIGHT

dialogues.text: They’re all set up watching a movie. They have nuggets, pizza and carrot sticks and they’re happy.
Most Fridays. I couldn’t parent alone. I need other moms around.
I need at least one day a week that I don’t have to figure out what’s for dinner.
This is why people have sister wives.
I don’t have any friends that are moms.
We were surprised you finally joined us.
Well... I guess I’ve kind of hit a breaking point. My husband and I are getting a separation and I killed our cat this week, and it just made me realize I’m not doing so great. Emotionally.
I let the fish die. Benign neglect. I didn’t want to clean the fucking bowl. The kids didn’t care.
I accidentally let Percy fly away.
The parakeet. I hated that bird.
But what happened with your husband?

We were so stuck in this horrible dynamic - me being a stay at home mom, which maybe I’m not cut out for, him being the worker who gets to leave and engage with the world. I had to break out of it before I totally lost my mind.
I don’t know yet; it’s really new - he’s staying at the Extended Stay
He wasn’t around that much before.
He’s taking him for the night tomorrow night - it will be the first time I’ve ever been away from my baby overnight.
It will be good. You’ll be okay.

scenes.actionPreview: 131 131 The moms are all sitting around the comfy overstuffed couches in the main room of Jen’s house sipping off wine, and picking from a beautiful cheese platter. Jen comes in from the other room carrying a bottle of wine. Who needs more wine? She comes and fills up the mother’s glass. Do you guys

scenes.heading: EXT. SUBURBAN STREET - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: 132 132 The mother puts her son into her husband’s car, clicking him into his carseat. She kisses him and watches them drive away. She turns back to her house, almost confused as to what to do next.

scenes.heading: INT. STUDIO - DAY
scenes.actionPreview: 133 133 The mother, in ratty art clothes, is alone in her office. She stands on a chair pulling things from the closet she hasn’t seen in years. scenes.heading: EXT. STREETS - EARLY EVENING
scenes.actionPreview: 135 135 The streetlights are just turning on, as the day turns to evening. The Mother, in her human form, jogs along the street. She pushes her body, running with a purpose. With each step she runs faster, happier. September 6, 2022 96 July 30, 2022 97 She runs past other houses with their lights on

She is laying a gold raccoon skeleton down on the canvas in pieces and trying to decide what should happen next. She is “in the zo

scenes.heading: INT. LIVING ROOM - MORNING
scenes.actionPreview: 138 138 The mother opens the door for her husband and son. She is showered, dressed for the day and bright eyed. She hugs her son and kisses him all over. Then hugs her husband, which surprises him a bit. How did it go? They come in and all walk into the kitchen.

scenes.heading: INT. KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.text: We had a good night, didn’t we, dude? It was hard. I’m not gonna lie. It was... hard. He missed you.
How was your first night alone?
It was really wonderful, actually. I think I have an idea for a new project. I’m just really focused.

scenes.actionPreview: 139 139 The kitchen is cleaner than we’ve ever seen it. The husband clocks this. On the table is orange juice, a stack of pancakes and frozen hash brown cakes all browned and delicious looking. The husband starts helping himself. And my place is... a little weird. Sterile. The mother smiles. Septemb

scenes.heading: INT. LIVING ROOM - LATER

dialogues.text: So I’ll drop him off Friday morning?
That’s a good idea. I’ll send you the link for that dinosaur he loves. You could get him one for your place. And I’ll pack more for him too.
That will change. This is gonna be good for both of you.

He’s like ‘who is this weird man living in this sad apartment complex with all the other sad men?’ I swear the whole place is newly divorced dads. All these kids at the pool kind of just confused - not a mom in sight.
I just picture all the kids getting sunburned because nobody remembers the sunscreen.
Oh man, I didn’t even think of sunscreen.
Okay! What do we want to do today? I missed you so much.

scenes.actionPreview: 140 140 The mother is walking the husband to the door, while the son plays with trains on the floor in the living room. Okay. Yeah. I need to get some toys at my place. He was so bored. And maybe a stuffy or something? The vibe is not tense between them, but a bit awkward. July 30, 2022 99 July 30,

dialogues.text: ...And scream at you ‘you’re amazing! You’re my mother!
Go to Europe. Insist on your joy!

scenes.heading: INT. GALLERY - DAY

dialogues.text: (speaking to herself while screwing hooks into the ceiling) I always thought motherhood was sort of a weak state of being - like very basic and passive. But motherhood is a far more primal active thing than that. (MORE)

scenes.actionPreview: 146 146 Our mother is installing her pieces into a large gorgeous gallery with huge ceilings - it’s the type of hip chic gallery from her former life. scenes.heading: INT. GALLERY - LATER

dialogues.text: I feel like everyone is looking at me. I can’t get used to it.
Really? It feels awesome to me.
(to the mother) I’m just really impressed by you.
Is it true the times is here?
I feel like I should try to talk to
This is pretty fucking cool - especially for the suburbs.
I’m really into this show- like blown away. It’s very provocative.
It reminds me a little bit of
Thank you for listening to the call.
You did it. You listened. They called. You answered.

I’m gonna go relieve the sitter.

I can’t believe * I got her out of the city. * She laughs a little to herself, and looks to the hus

scenes.heading: INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT

dialogues.text: There are times when I look to my son and I cannot tell where he begins and I end. He is that much a part of me.
(to the son in a bear voice)
This must be what it is to be an animal. To look at another and say ‘I am so much that other thing that we are part of one another’.
(in a bear voice) I want blackberries.
(as a bear) I’ll get blackberries and Santa.
He said salmon not Santa, baby.
You say ‘here is my skin. Here is yours. Beneath the moon we pile inside the warm cave, becoming one creature to save our warmth’.
Okay I got blackberries and Santa’s candy canes... and his head.
What? We’ve got Santa’s head here to eat?
This is how it’s always been and how it will continue to be.

scenes.actionPreview: 150 150 Under a home-made fort. The son, mother and husband are huddled with a flashlight in a sort of magical cave. Be bears. The mother and husband assume their bear positions- paws up, on their haunches. The mother opens her mouth and a real bear roar comes out - loud and clear. The husband opens

scenes.heading: INT. LIVING ROOM - DAY

dialogues.text: Yes yes. You’re doing so well.
AHHHHH! I can’t. I can’t do it.
Listen to me. You can do this. You were made to do this. Your mother did this. Her mother did this. It’s time to dig deep and find the strength because it’s time to meet your daughter. NOW!

scenes.actionPreview: 151 151 * Close up on the mother’s face. She is sweating, veins popping on her head, guttural sounds coming from her. Pull out to reveal she is squatting, partially draped in a gown, in very active labor, a huge bulging belly. This is not the labor we tend to see in movies. This is real labor. Blood
